title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:

· Zooplankton

· Ducks

· Small fish

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify a population of organisms that likely has the highest amount of energy available in the food web, such as any of the following:

· Phytoplankton

· Aquatic plants

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why a decrease in the wading bird population would likely lead to an increase in the biomass in the large fish population in the short term, such as any of the following:

· The wading birds and the large fish compete for small fish; if there are fewer wading birds, then there would likely be more food available for the large fish or less competition for the prey.

· Wading birds and large fish specialize in the same prey, so if there are fewer wading birds, there would be more food available for the large fish or less competition for the prey.

The response explains why a decrease in the wading bird population would likely lead to an increase in the biomass in the large fish population in the short term, such as one of the following:

· The wading birds and the large fish compete for small fish; if there are fewer wading birds, then there would likely be more food available for the large fish or less competition for the prey.

· Wading birds and large fish specialize in the same prey, so if there are fewer wading birds, there would be more food available for the large fish or less competition for the prey.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one likely environmental problem in the Chesapeake Bay that results from the generation of electricity for Baltimore, such as any of the following:

· Power plants that burn fossil fuels produce oxides of nitrogen and sulfur that cause acid rain, which can affect the pH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabchacaqGibaaaa@39B7@ of the bay.

· Nitrogen oxides from power plants can fall into the bay and cause eutrophication.

· Coal-burning power plants produce mercury-containing particulate matter that can fall into the bay when it rains; mercury is harmful to aquatic organisms.

· Power plants that use water from the bay to cool equipment may contribute thermal pollution to the bay. The change in water temperature is harmful to aquatic organisms.

· Power plants that burn fossil fuels produce oxides of nitrogen and sulfur that cause acid rain, which can affect the pH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabchacaqGibaaaa@39B7@ of the bay.

· Nitrogen oxides from power plants can fall into the bay and cause eutrophication.

· Coal-burning power plants produce mercury-containing particulate matter that can fall into the bay when it rains; mercury is harmful to aquatic organisms.

· Power plants that use water from the bay to cool equipment may contribute thermal pollution to the bay. The change in water temperature is harmful to aquatic organisms.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim that proposes a realistic solution to the problem identified in part (e), such as any of the following:

· Implementing/enforcing air pollution regulatory practices (e.g., scrubbers, electrostatic precipitators) in power plants would decrease the release of the air pollutants that are produced when fossil fuels are combusted.

· Switching to a renewable energy source for producing electricity would decrease the production of the air pollutants that are released when fossil fuels are combusted.

· Creating cooling ponds instead of using water from the bay would prevent thermal pollution in the bay.

· Increasing the use of nuclear energy would decrease the production of the air pollutants that are released when fossil fuels are combusted.

· Creating cooling ponds instead of using water from the bay would prevent thermal pollution in the bay.

· Increasing the use of nuclear energy would decrease the production of the air pollutants that are released when fossil fuels are combusted.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one additional benefit that could result from the implementation of the solution proposed in part (f), such as any of the following:

Implementing/enforcing air pollution regulatory practices (e.g., scrubbers, electrostatic precipitators) in power plants (solution in part (f)).

· Less air pollution benefits human health

· Seafood contains less mercury

Switching to a renewable energy source for producing electricity (solution in part (f)).

· Less mining for coal, drilling for oil/gas

· Less transport of fossil fuels from source to power plants so less chance of accidents/spills/releases from pipelines etc.

· Decreases emissions of greenhouse gases

Creating cooling ponds instead of using water from the bay (solution in part (f)).

· Creates aquatic habitat for wildlife

· Increases recreational opportunities (e.g., boating, fishing)

Increasing the use of nuclear energy (solution in part (f)).

· Seafood contains less mercury

· Less mining for coal, drilling for oil/gas

· Less transport of fossil fuels from source to power plants so less chance of accidents/spills/releases from pipelines etc.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one unintended consequence that the loss of woodlands can have on the Chesapeake Bay, such as any of the following:

· The deforestation/increase in impervious surfaces can lead to flooding in the rivers that lead to the bay.

· Increased sediment runoff can choke submerged aqueous vegetation in the bay or bury habitat used by many organisms.

· Increased flooding can cause an influx of excess nutrients into the bay, causing eutrophication.

The response describes one unintended consequence that the loss of woodlands can have on the Chesapeake Bay, such as one of the following:

· The deforestation/increase in impervious surfaces can lead to flooding in the rivers that lead to the bay.

· Increased sediment runoff can choke submerged aqueous vegetation in the bay or bury habitat used by many organisms.

· Increased flooding can cause an influx of excess nutrients into the bay, causing eutrophication.
